In 1823 Canning wrote that he took Burke's "last works and words [as] the manual of my politics". The Conservative Prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli "was deeply penetrated with the spirit and sentiment of Burke's later writings".
text_ai_base: In the nineteenth century, both liberals and conservatives praised Edmund Burke. His friend Philip Francis noted that Burke "truly and prophetically foresaw all the consequences that would arise from adopting French principles," yet his passionate writing led some to doubt his arguments. William Windham, speaking from the same bench in the House of Commons as Burke did after his split from Fox, was described by an observer as speaking "like the ghost of Burke" during his 1801 speech against peace with France. Despite being a political adversary, William Hazlitt ranked Burke among his three favorite writers, alongside Junius and Rousseau, and considered it a mark of sense and fairness for someone from the opposing party to recognize Burke's greatness. Initially a supporter of the French Revolution, William Wordsworth attacked Burke in 'A Letter to the Bishop of Llandaff' (1793). However, by the early nineteenth century, Wordsworth had changed his mind and admired Burke. In his Two Addresses to the Freeholders of Westmorland, Wordsworth described Burke as "the most sagacious Politician of his age," noting that time had verified his predictions. Later, Wordsworth revised his poem The Prelude to incorporate praise for Burke ("Genius of Burke! forgive the pen seduced/By specious wonders"), depicting him as an old oak. Similarly, Samuel Taylor Coleridge experienced a transformation in his views; he had criticized Burke in The Watchman, but defended him against charges of inconsistency in The Friend (1809–10). In Biographia Literaria (1817), Coleridge praised Burke as a prophet who "habitually referred to principles," calling him a scientific statesman and thus a visionary. Henry Brougham noted that Burke's predictions had largely been fulfilled, highlighting the chaos and bloodshed in France, as well as the upheaval in Europe. George Canning stated that Burke's Reflections had been validated by subsequent events, with nearly every prophecy fulfilled. In 1823, Canning admitted that he considered Burke's "last works and words [as] the manual of my politics." The Conservative Prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli was said to be deeply influenced by the spirit and sentiment of Burke's later writings.

text_human: 6th-century BCE pre-Socratic Greek philosophers Thales of Miletus and Xenophanes of Colophon were the first in the region to attempt to explain the world in terms of human reason rather than myth and tradition, thus can be said to be the first Greek humanists. Thales questioned the notion of anthropomorphic gods and Xenophanes refused to recognise the gods of his time and reserved the divine for the principle of unity in the universe. These Ionian Greeks were the first thinkers to assert that nature is available to be studied separately from the supernatural realm. Anaxagoras brought philosophy and the spirit of rational inquiry from Ionia to Athens. Pericles, the leader of Athens during the period of its greatest glory was an admirer of Anaxagoras. Other influential pre-Socratics or rational philosophers include Protagoras (like Anaxagoras a friend of Pericles), known for his famous dictum "man is the measure of all things" and Democritus, who proposed that matter was composed of atoms. Little of the written work of these early philosophers survives and they are known mainly from fragments and quotations in other writers, principally Plato and Aristotle. The historian Thucydides, noted for his scientific and rational approach to history, is also much admired by later humanists. In the 3rd century BCE, Epicurus became known for his concise phrasing of the problem of evil, lack of belief in the afterlife, and human-centred approaches to achieving eudaimonia. He was also the first Greek philosopher to admit women to his school as a rule.
text_ai_base: In the 6th century BCE, pre-Socratic Greek philosophers Thales of Miletus and Xenophanes of Colophon paved the way for explaining the world through human reason rather than through myth and tradition, marking them as the first Greek humanists. Thales questioned the concept of anthropomorphic gods, while Xenophanes rejected the deities of his era, instead attributing divinity to the principle of unity in the universe. These Ionian philosophers pioneered the idea that nature could be studied independently of the supernatural. Anaxagoras transplanted philosophy and a spirit of rational inquiry from Ionia to Athens, where he was admired by Pericles, Athens' leader during its golden age. Other notable pre-Socratic philosophers include Protagoras, a friend of Pericles, known for his dictum "man is the measure of all things," and Democritus, who introduced the idea that matter is composed of atoms. Although much of their writings have been lost, these early thinkers are mainly known through fragments and quotations in the works of later philosophers like Plato and Aristotle. The historian Thucydides, renowned for his scientific and rational historical approach, is also highly esteemed by later humanists. In the 3rd century BCE, Epicurus became notable for articulating the problem of evil, his disbelief in an afterlife, and his focus on human-centered methods for achieving eudaimonia. Epicurus was also the first Greek philosopher to regularly admit women into his school.

text_human: Strict separation of powers did not operate in The United Kingdom, the political structure of which served in most instances[citation needed] as a model for the government created by the U.S. Constitution.[citation needed] Under the UK Westminster system, based on parliamentary sovereignty and responsible government, Parliament (consisting of the Sovereign (King-in-Parliament), House of Lords and House of Commons) was the supreme lawmaking authority. The executive branch acted in the name of the King ("His Majesty's Government"), as did the judiciary. The King's Ministers were in most cases members of one of the two Houses of Parliament, and the Government needed to sustain the support of a majority in the House of Commons. One minister, the Lord Chancellor, was at the same time the sole judge in the Court of Chancery and the presiding officer in the House of Lords. Therefore, it may be seen that the three branches of British government often violated the strict principle of separation of powers, even though there were many occasions when the different branches of the government disagreed with each other. Some U.S. states did not observe a strict separation of powers in the 18th century. In New Jersey, the Governor also functioned as a member of the state's highest court and as the presiding officer of one house of the New Jersey Legislature. The President of Delaware was a member of the Court of Appeals; the presiding officers of the two houses of the state legislature also served in the executive department as Vice Presidents. In both Delaware and Pennsylvania, members of the executive council served at the same time as judges. On the other hand, many southern states explicitly required separation of powers. Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina and Georgia all kept the branches of government "separate and distinct."
text_ai_base: The United Kingdom did not adhere to a strict separation of powers, although its political structure often served as a model for the U.S. Constitution. The UK operates under the Westminster system, which is characterized by parliamentary sovereignty and responsible government. In this system, Parliament, which includes the Sovereign (King-in-Parliament), the House of Lords, and the House of Commons, is the ultimate lawmaking body. The executive branch and judiciary functioned in the name of the King, referred to as "His Majesty's Government." Most of the King's Ministers were members of either the House of Lords or the House of Commons, and the government needed the support of a majority in the House of Commons. One minister, the Lord Chancellor, simultaneously served as the sole judge in the Court of Chancery and the presiding officer in the House of Lords. As a result, the separation of powers in the British government was often not strictly observed, even though conflicts between different branches did occur. Similarly, some U.S. states in the 18th century did not strictly separate powers. For example, New Jersey's Governor also served on the state's highest court and presided over one house of the legislature. In Delaware, the President was a member of the Court of Appeals, and legislative leaders served in the executive role as Vice Presidents. Delaware and Pennsylvania had executive council members who also served as judges. However, many southern states required a clear separation of powers, with Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, and Georgia ensuring their branches of government remained "separate and distinct."

text_human: On December 13, 2013, Beyoncé unexpectedly released her eponymous fifth studio album on the iTunes Store without any prior announcement or promotion. The album debuted atop the Billboard 200 chart, giving Beyoncé her fifth consecutive number-one album in the US. This made her the first woman in the chart's history to have her first five studio albums debut at number one. Beyoncé received critical acclaim and commercial success, selling one million digital copies worldwide in six days; The New York Times noted the album's unconventional, unexpected release as significant. Musically an electro-R&B album, it concerns darker themes previously unexplored in her work, such as "bulimia, postnatal depression [and] the fears and insecurities of marriage and motherhood". The single "Drunk in Love", featuring Jay Z, peaked at number two on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. In April 2014, after much speculation in the weeks before, Beyoncé and Jay Z officially announced their On the Run Tour. It served as the couple's first co-headlining stadium tour together. On August 24, 2014, she received the Video Vanguard Award at the 2014 MTV Video Music Awards. Knowles also took home three competitive awards: Best Video with a Social Message and Best Cinematography for "Pretty Hurts", as well as best collaboration for "Drunk in Love". In November, Forbes reported that Beyoncé was the top-earning woman in music for the second year in a row—earning $115 million in the year, more than double her earnings in 2013. Beyoncé was reissued with new material in three forms: as an extended play, a box set, as well as a full platinum edition.
text_ai_base: On December 13, 2013, Beyoncé surprised the world by releasing her self-titled fifth studio album on iTunes without any prior announcement or promotional effort. The album immediately topped the Billboard 200 chart, marking Beyoncé's fifth consecutive number-one album in the US and making her the first woman in history to have her first five studio albums debut at number one. The album was met with widespread critical acclaim and commercial success, selling one million digital copies worldwide in just six days. The New York Times highlighted the album’s unconventional release as a significant event. Musically, it is an electro-R&B album exploring darker themes that Beyoncé had not previously addressed, such as bulimia, postnatal depression, and the fears and insecurities of marriage and motherhood. The single "Drunk in Love," featuring Jay Z, reached number two on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. After weeks of speculation, Beyoncé and Jay Z announced their On the Run Tour in April 2014, their first co-headlining stadium tour. On August 24, 2014, Beyoncé received the Video Vanguard Award at the MTV Video Music Awards and won three additional awards: Best Video with a Social Message and Best Cinematography for "Pretty Hurts," and Best Collaboration for "Drunk in Love." In November, Forbes revealed that Beyoncé was the highest-earning woman in music for the second consecutive year, making $115 million, more than double her earnings in 2013. The album "Beyoncé" was reissued with new material in three formats: an extended play, a box set, and a full platinum edition.

text_human: The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. The Klan decided to have a week-long Klavern in South Bend. Clashes with the student body started on March 17, when students, aware of the anti-Catholic animosity, blocked the Klansmen from descending from their trains in the South Bend station and ripped the KKK clothes and regalia. On May 19 thousands of students massed downtown protesting the Klavern, and only the arrival of college president Fr. Matthew Walsh prevented any further clashes. The next day, football coach Knute Rockne spoke at a campus rally and implored the students to obey the college president and refrain from further violence. A few days later the Klavern broke up, but the hostility shown by the students was an omen and a contribution to the downfall of the KKK in Indiana.
text_ai_base: Notre Dame gained widespread recognition due to the success of its football team, which reflected the rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics united in support of the team, often listening to games on the radio, particularly when Notre Dame defeated schools representing the Protestant establishment in America, such as Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. However, Notre Dame's role as a leading Catholic institution also made it a target for anti-Catholic sentiment. A notable instance of violence occurred in 1924 when Notre Dame students clashed with the Ku Klux Klan. The KKK, known for promoting nativism and anti-Catholicism, viewed Notre Dame as a symbol of the Catholic Church's perceived threat. During a week-long Klavern in South Bend, tensions peaked on March 17, when students, aware of the Klan's hostile views, prevented Klansmen from disembarking their trains at the South Bend station, tearing apart their clothing and regalia. On May 19, thousands of students gathered downtown to protest the Klavern, and potential conflicts were avoided only by the intervention of college president Fr. Matthew Walsh. The following day, football coach Knute Rockne addressed the campus rally, urging students to follow the president's guidance and cease any violent actions. Shortly thereafter, the Klavern disbanded, but the student opposition foreshadowed and contributed to the KKK's decline in Indiana.

text_human: The last major building work took place during the reign of King George V when, in 1913, Sir Aston Webb redesigned Blore's 1850 East Front to resemble in part Giacomo Leoni's Lyme Park in Cheshire. This new, refaced principal façade (of Portland stone) was designed to be the backdrop to the Victoria Memorial, a large memorial statue of Queen Victoria, placed outside the main gates. George V, who had succeeded Edward VII in 1910, had a more serious personality than his father; greater emphasis was now placed on official entertaining and royal duties than on lavish parties. He arranged a series of command performances featuring jazz musicians such as the Original Dixieland Jazz Band (1919) – the first jazz performance for a head of state, Sidney Bechet, and Louis Armstrong (1932), which earned the palace a nomination in 2009 for a (Kind of) Blue Plaque by the Brecon Jazz Festival as one of the venues making the greatest contribution to jazz music in the United Kingdom. George V's wife Queen Mary was a connoisseur of the arts, and took a keen interest in the Royal Collection of furniture and art, both restoring and adding to it. Queen Mary also had many new fixtures and fittings installed, such as the pair of marble Empire-style chimneypieces by Benjamin Vulliamy, dating from 1810, which the Queen had installed in the ground floor Bow Room, the huge low room at the centre of the garden façade. Queen Mary was also responsible for the decoration of the Blue Drawing Room. This room, 69 feet (21 metres) long, previously known as the South Drawing Room, has a ceiling designed specially by Nash, coffered with huge gilt console brackets.
text_ai_base: During King George V's reign, the last significant construction occurred in 1913 when Sir Aston Webb redesigned Blore's 1850 East Front to partly mirror Giacomo Leoni's Lyme Park in Cheshire. The revitalized main façade, crafted from Portland stone, was intended as the backdrop for the Victoria Memorial—a grand statue of Queen Victoria—placed outside the palace's main gates. Upon succeeding Edward VII in 1910, George V, whose personality was more serious compared to his father, shifted the focus from extravagant parties to official engagements and royal responsibilities. He organized a series of command performances featuring jazz artists like the Original Dixieland Jazz Band in 1919—the first jazz act for a head of state—followed by Sidney Bechet and Louis Armstrong in 1932. This led to the palace's nomination in 2009 for a (Kind of) Blue Plaque by the Brecon Jazz Festival, highlighting its significant contribution to jazz music in the UK. Queen Mary, George V’s wife, was an art enthusiast who actively engaged with the Royal Collection, restoring and expanding it. She introduced numerous new features, including a pair of marble Empire-style chimneypieces by Benjamin Vulliamy, originally from 1810, installed in the Bow Room on the ground floor—the large central room on the garden façade. Queen Mary also oversaw the decor of the Blue Drawing Room, which spans 69 feet (21 meters). Previously known as the South Drawing Room, its ceiling features a design by Nash with coffered details and grand gilt console brackets.

text_human: Asian Americans in New York City, according to the 2010 Census, number more than one million, greater than the combined totals of San Francisco and Los Angeles. New York contains the highest total Asian population of any U.S. city proper. The New York City borough of Queens is home to the state's largest Asian American population and the largest Andean (Colombian, Ecuadorian, Peruvian, and Bolivian) populations in the United States, and is also the most ethnically diverse urban area in the world. The Chinese population constitutes the fastest-growing nationality in New York State; multiple satellites of the original Manhattan Chinatown (紐約華埠), in Brooklyn (布鲁克林華埠), and around Flushing, Queens (法拉盛華埠), are thriving as traditionally urban enclaves, while also expanding rapidly eastward into suburban Nassau County (拿騷縣) on Long Island (長島), as the New York metropolitan region and New York State have become the top destinations for new Chinese immigrants, respectively, and large-scale Chinese immigration continues into New York City and surrounding areas. In 2012, 6.3% of New York City was of Chinese ethnicity, with nearly three-fourths living in either Queens or Brooklyn, geographically on Long Island. A community numbering 20,000 Korean-Chinese (Chaoxianzu (Chinese: 朝鲜族) or Joseonjok (Hangul: 조선족)) is centered in Flushing, Queens, while New York City is also home to the largest Tibetan population outside China, India, and Nepal, also centered in Queens. Koreans made up 1.2% of the city's population, and Japanese 0.3%. Filipinos were the largest Southeast Asian ethnic group at 0.8%, followed by Vietnamese, who made up 0.2% of New York City's population in 2010. Indians are the largest South Asian group, comprising 2.4% of the city's population, with Bangladeshis and Pakistanis at 0.7% and 0.5%, respectively. Queens is the preferred borough of settlement for Asian Indians, Koreans, and Filipinos, as well as Malaysians and other Southeast Asians; while Brooklyn is receiving large numbers of both West Indian as well as Asian Indian immigrants.
text_ai_base: According to the 2010 Census, Asian Americans in New York City number over a million, surpassing the combined totals of San Francisco and Los Angeles. New York City boasts the largest Asian population of any U.S. city. The borough of Queens has the highest Asian American population in the state and hosts the largest Andean populations—Colombian, Ecuadorian, Peruvian, and Bolivian—in the U.S. It is also the most ethnically diverse urban area globally. The Chinese are the fastest-growing nationality in New York State, with multiple satellite Chinatowns thriving in Brooklyn and Flushing, Queens, while expanding into suburban Nassau County on Long Island. The New York metropolitan area and New York State are top destinations for new Chinese immigrants, fostering continued large-scale immigration into the city and its surroundings. In 2012, 6.3% of New Yorkers were of Chinese ethnicity, with nearly three-fourths residing in Queens or Brooklyn, which are geographically on Long Island. Flushing, Queens, houses a community of 20,000 Korean-Chinese, while New York City hosts the largest Tibetan population outside China, India, and Nepal, largely centered in Queens. Koreans comprised 1.2% of the city's population, and Japanese 0.3%. Filipinos were the largest Southeast Asian group at 0.8%, followed by Vietnamese at 0.2% in 2010. Indians, the largest South Asian group, made up 2.4% of the city's population, with Bangladeshis and Pakistanis at 0.7% and 0.5%, respectively. Queens is the preferred borough for Asian Indians, Koreans, and Filipinos, as well as Malaysians and other Southeast Asians. Brooklyn, on the other hand, is attracting increasing numbers of West Indian and Asian Indian immigrants.

text_human: The polyphony of Christian a cappella music began to develop in Europe around the late 15th century, with compositions by Josquin des Prez. The early a cappella polyphonies may have had an accompanying instrument, although this instrument would merely double the singers' parts and was not independent. By the 16th century, a cappella polyphony had further developed, but gradually, the cantata began to take the place of a cappella forms. 16th century a cappella polyphony, nonetheless, continued to influence church composers throughout this period and to the present day. Recent evidence has shown that some of the early pieces by Palestrina, such as what was written for the Sistine Chapel was intended to be accompanied by an organ "doubling" some or all of the voices. Such is seen in the life of Palestrina becoming a major influence on Bach, most notably in the aforementioned Mass in B Minor. Other composers that utilized the a cappella style, if only for the occasional piece, were Claudio Monteverdi and his masterpiece, Lagrime d'amante al sepolcro dell'amata (A lover's tears at his beloved's grave), which was composed in 1610, and Andrea Gabrieli when upon his death it was discovered many choral pieces, one of which was in the unaccompanied style. Learning from the preceding two composeres, Heinrich Schütz utilized the a cappella style in numerous pieces, chief among these were the pieces in the oratorio style, which were traditionally performed during the Easter week and dealt with the religious subject matter of that week, such as Christ's suffering and the Passion. Five of Schutz's Historien were Easter pieces, and of these the latter three, which dealt with the passion from three different viewpoints, those of Matthew, Luke and John, were all done a cappella style. This was a near requirement for this type of piece, and the parts of the crowd were sung while the solo parts which were the quoted parts from either Christ or the authors were performed in a plainchant.
text_ai_base: The development of Christian a cappella music in Europe began around the late 15th century with compositions by Josquin des Prez. Early polyphonic works sometimes included instrumental accompaniment, but instruments merely duplicated the singers' parts rather than acting independently. By the 16th century, a cappella polyphony had evolved significantly, although the cantata gradually began to replace it in popularity. Despite this shift, 16th-century a cappella polyphony continued to influence church composers both during and beyond that period. Recent evidence suggests that some of Palestrina's early works, such as those written for the Sistine Chapel, were meant to be accompanied by an organ that "doubled" some or all of the voices. Palestrina greatly influenced Bach, particularly in his Mass in B Minor. Other composers who occasionally employed the a cappella style include Claudio Monteverdi, known for his 1610 masterpiece "Lagrime d'amante al sepolcro dell'amata" ("A Lover's Tears at His Beloved's Grave"), and Andrea Gabrieli, whose unaccompanied choral works were discovered posthumously. Influenced by these predecessors, Heinrich Schütz used the a cappella style in many of his compositions, especially those in the oratorio style, which were traditionally performed during Easter week. These works often focused on religious themes, such as Christ's suffering and the Passion. Among Schütz's five "Historien" pieces for Easter, the final three—depicting the Passion from Matthew, Luke, and John—were performed a cappella. This style was almost essential for such compositions, where crowd parts were sung and solo parts, often representing Christ or the Gospel authors, were delivered in plainchant.

text_human: Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles give a long critique of the application of FST to human populations in their 2003 paper "Human Genetic Diversity and the Nonexistence of Biological Races". They find that the figure of 85% is misleading because it implies that all human populations contain on average 85% of all genetic diversity. They claim that this does not correctly reflect human population history, because it treats all human groups as independent. A more realistic portrayal of the way human groups are related is to understand that some human groups are parental to other groups and that these groups represent paraphyletic groups to their descent groups. For example, under the recent African origin theory the human population in Africa is paraphyletic to all other human groups because it represents the ancestral group from which all non-African populations derive, but more than that, non-African groups only derive from a small non-representative sample of this African population. This means that all non-African groups are more closely related to each other and to some African groups (probably east Africans) than they are to others, and further that the migration out of Africa represented a genetic bottleneck, with much of the diversity that existed in Africa not being carried out of Africa by the emigrating groups. This view produces a version of human population movements that do not result in all human populations being independent; but rather, produces a series of dilutions of diversity the further from Africa any population lives, each founding event representing a genetic subset of its parental population. Long and Kittles find that rather than 85% of human genetic diversity existing in all human populations, about 100% of human diversity exists in a single African population, whereas only about 70% of human genetic diversity exists in a population derived from New Guinea. Long and Kittles argued that this still produces a global human population that is genetically homogeneous compared to other mammalian populations.
text_ai_base: In their 2003 paper "Human Genetic Diversity and the Nonexistence of Biological Races," Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles critically examine the use of FST in assessing human populations. They argue that the commonly cited figure of 85% is misleading, as it suggests that each human group contains, on average, 85% of the global genetic diversity. This perspective inaccurately represents human population history by treating all groups as independent entities. A more accurate depiction recognizes that some groups are ancestral to others, illustrating a paraphyletic relationship with their descendant groups. According to the recent African origin theory, the African population is paraphyletic to all non-African groups, serving as the ancestral source from which non-Africans emerge. Importantly, non-African populations arose from a small, non-representative subset of the African population. Consequently, non-African groups share a closer genetic relationship with each other and certain African groups (likely East Africans) than with other African populations. This migration out of Africa resulted in a genetic bottleneck, leaving much of the original African diversity behind. This interpretation of human population movements suggests that rather than being independent, human groups experienced a dilution of genetic diversity the farther they moved from Africa. Each migration event represented a genetic subset of its original population. Long and Kittles found that, rather than 85%, a single African population holds almost all human genetic diversity, while a population from New Guinea retains only about 70%. Despite this, Long and Kittles conclude that globally, human populations are genetically homogeneous when compared to other mammalian populations.

text_human: Emotions can motivate social interactions and relationships and therefore are directly related with basic physiology, particularly with the stress systems. This is important because emotions are related to the anti-stress complex, with an oxytocin-attachment system, which plays a major role in bonding. Emotional phenotype temperaments affect social connectedness and fitness in complex social systems (Kurt Kortschal 2013). These characteristics are shared with other species and taxa and are due to the effects of genes and their continuous transmission. Information that is encoded in the DNA sequences provides the blueprint for assembling proteins that make up our cells. Zygotes require genetic information from their parental germ cells, and at every speciation event, heritable traits that have enabled its ancestor to survive and reproduce successfully are passed down along with new traits that could be potentially beneficial to the offspring. In the five million years since the linages leading to modern humans and chimpanzees split, only about 1.2% of their genetic material has been modified. This suggests that everything that separates us from chimpanzees must be encoded in that very small amount of DNA, including our behaviors. Students that study animal behaviors have only identified intraspecific examples of gene-dependent behavioral phenotypes. In voles (Microtus spp.) minor genetic differences have been identified in a vasopressin receptor gene that corresponds to major species differences in social organization and the mating system (Hammock & Young 2005). Another potential example with behavioral differences is the FOCP2 gene, which is involved in neural circuitry handling speech and language (Vargha-Khadem et al. 2005). Its present form in humans differed from that of the chimpanzees by only a few mutations and has been present for about 200,000 years, coinciding with the beginning of modern humans (Enard et al. 2002). Speech, language, and social organization are all part of the basis for emotions.
text_ai_base: Emotions play a crucial role in motivating social interactions and forming relationships. They are closely linked to basic physiology, particularly the stress systems, and are related to the anti-stress complex, particularly the oxytocin attachment system, which is vital for bonding. Emotional temperaments influence social connectedness and overall fitness within complex social structures (Kurt Kortschal 2013). These traits are seen across species due to genetic effects and their continuous inheritance. DNA sequences encode information that serves as a blueprint for protein assembly in cells. Zygotes require genetic information from parental germ cells, passing down heritable traits that aided ancestors in survival and reproduction. Since the divergence of human and chimpanzee lineages about five million years ago, only around 1.2% of their genetic material has changed, implying that the differences, including behavioral ones, are contained within this small DNA segment. Studies of animal behavior reveal intraspecific examples of gene-dependent behavioral traits. For example, minor genetic variations in a vasopressin receptor gene among voles (Microtus spp.) correspond to significant differences in species-specific social organization and mating systems (Hammock & Young 2005). Another example is the FOCP2 gene, which affects neural circuits related to speech and language (Vargha-Khadem et al. 2005). This gene's form in humans, which has only slightly mutated from its chimpanzee version, has been around for approximately 200,000 years, aligning with the emergence of modern humans (Enard et al. 2002). Speech, language, and social organization underlie emotional expression.

text_human: In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12-inch records. Eddie Condon explained: "Gabler realized that a jam session needs room for development." The first two 12-inch recordings did not take advantage of the extra length: "Carnegie Drag" was 3:15; "Carnegie Jump", 2:41. But at the second session, on April 30, the two 12-inch recordings were longer: "Embraceable You" was 4:05; "Serenade to a Shylock", 4:32. Another way around the time limitation was to issue a selection on both sides of a single record. Vaudeville stars Gallagher and Shean recorded "Mr. Gallagher and Mr. Shean", written by Irving and Jack Kaufman, as two sides of a 10-inch 78 in 1922 for Cameo. An obvious workaround for longer recordings was to release a set of records. An early multi-record release was in 1903, when HMV in England made the first complete recording of an opera, Verdi's Ernani, on 40 single-sided discs. In 1940, Commodore released Eddie Condon and his Band's recording of "A Good Man Is Hard to Find" in four parts, issued on both sides of two 12-inch 78s. This limitation on the duration of recordings persisted from 1910 until the invention of the LP record, in 1948. In popular music, this time limitation of about 3:30 on a 10-inch 78 rpm record meant that singers usually did not release long pieces on record. One exception is Frank Sinatra's recording of Rodgers and Hammerstein's "Soliloquy", from Carousel, made on May 28, 1946. Because it ran 7:57, longer than both sides of a standard 78 rpm 10-inch record, it was released on Columbia's Masterwork label (the classical division) as two sides of a 12-inch record. The same was true of John Raitt's performance of the song on the original cast album of Carousel, which had been issued on a 78-rpm album set by American Decca in 1945.
text_ai_base: In January 1938, Milt Gabler began recording for his new label, Commodore Records, using 12-inch records to enable longer performances. Eddie Condon noted: "Gabler understood that a jam session needs space to develop." Although the first two 12-inch recordings, "Carnegie Drag" (3:15) and "Carnegie Jump" (2:41), didn't utilize the extra time, subsequent recordings, such as "Embraceable You" (4:05) and "Serenade to a Shylock" (4:32), did. Another way to overcome time constraints was by splitting a song across both sides of a record. For instance, vaudeville stars Gallagher and Shean recorded "Mr. Gallagher and Mr. Shean" by Irving and Jack Kaufman as two sides of a 10-inch 78 in 1922 for Cameo. A more evident solution for longer pieces was releasing multiple records as a set. HMV in England made the first complete opera recording with Verdi's Ernani in 1903, using 40 single-sided discs. In 1940, Commodore released Eddie Condon and his Band's "A Good Man Is Hard to Find" in four parts, across two 12-inch 78s. Until the LP record's invention in 1948, recordings were typically limited to about 3:30 per side, which often restricted singers from releasing lengthy music pieces. An exception was Frank Sinatra's recording of Rodgers and Hammerstein's "Soliloquy" from Carousel, on May 28, 1946. Running 7:57, it required two sides of a 12-inch record, released by Columbia's Masterwork label, their classical division. Similarly, John Raitt's rendition of the song on Carousel's original cast album was part of a 78-rpm album set by American Decca in 1945.

text_human: The landscapes of Thuringia are quite diverse. The far north is occupied by the Harz mountains, followed by the Goldene Aue, a fertile floodplain around Nordhausen with the Helme as most important river. The north-west includes the Eichsfeld, a hilly and sometimes forested region, where the Leine river emanates. The central and northern part of Thuringia is defined by the 3000 km² wide Thuringian Basin, a very fertile and flat area around the Unstrut river and completely surrounded by the following hill chains (clockwise from the north-west): Dün, Hainleite, Windleite, Kyffhäuser, Hohe Schrecke, Schmücke, Finne, Ettersberg, Steigerwald, Thuringian Forest, Hörselberge and Hainich. Within the Basin the smaller hill chains Fahner Höhe and Heilinger Höhen. South of the Thuringian Basin is the Land's largest mountain range, marked by the Thuringian Forest in the north-west, the Thuringian Highland in the middle and the Franconian Forest in the south-east. Most of this range is forested and the Großer Beerberg (983 m) is Thuringia's highest mountain. To the south-west, the Forest is followed up by Werra river valley, dividing it from the Rhön Mountains in the west and the Grabfeld plain in the south. Eastern Thuringia, commonly described as the area east of Saale and Loquitz valley, is marked by a hilly landscape, rising slowly from the flat north to the mountainous south. The Saale in the west and the Weiße Elster in the east are the two big rivers running from south to north and forming densely settled valleys in this area. Between them lies the flat and forested Holzland in the north, the flat and fertile Orlasenke in the middle and the Vogtland, a hilly but in most parts non-forested region in the south. The far eastern region (east of Weiße Elster) is the Osterland or Altenburger Land along Pleiße river, a flat, fertile and densely settled agricultural area.
text_ai_base: Thuringia boasts a remarkably diverse landscape. In the far north, the region is characterized by the Harz Mountains, giving way to the Goldene Aue—a fertile floodplain enveloping Nordhausen, with the Helme River being its most significant waterway. To the northwest lies the Eichsfeld, a hilly and partially forested area where the Leine River originates. The central and northern parts of Thuringia are dominated by the expansive 3,000 km² Thuringian Basin, known for its flat, fertile land surrounding the Unstrut River. This basin is encircled by hill chains (clockwise from the northwest): Dün, Hainleite, Windleite, Kyffhäuser, Hohe Schrecke, Schmücke, Finne, Ettersberg, Steigerwald, Thuringian Forest, Hörselberge, and Hainich. Inside the basin, you'll find smaller hill chains like Fahner Höhe and Heilinger Höhen. South of the Thuringian Basin lies the state's largest mountain range, featuring the Thuringian Forest in the northwest, the Thuringian Highland in the center, and the Franconian Forest to the southeast. This mostly forested range includes Thuringia's highest peak, the Großer Beerberg (983 meters). To the southwest, the Werra River Valley separates the Forest from the Rhön Mountains to the west and the Grabfeld plain to the south. Eastern Thuringia, typically defined as the area east of the Saale and Loquitz valleys, features a landscape that gradually transitions from flat in the north to mountainous in the south. The Saale to the west and the Weiße Elster to the east are the area’s major rivers, flowing from south to north through densely populated valleys. Between these rivers lies the Holzland, a flat and forested region in the north; the Orlasenke, a flat and fertile area in the center; and the Vogtland, a hilly and mostly unwooded region in the south. The far eastern part (east of the Weiße Elster) is known as the Osterland or Altenburger Land, a flat, fertile, and densely populated agricultural area along the Pleiße River.

text_human: Nanjing ( listen; Chinese: 南京, "Southern Capital") is the city situated in the heartland of lower Yangtze River region in China, which has long been a major centre of culture, education, research, politics, economy, transport networks and tourism. It is the capital city of Jiangsu province of People's Republic of China and the second largest city in East China, with a total population of 8,216,100, and legally the capital of Republic of China which lost the mainland during the civil war. The city whose name means "Southern Capital" has a prominent place in Chinese history and culture, having served as the capitals of various Chinese dynasties, kingdoms and republican governments dating from the 3rd century AD to 1949. Prior to the advent of pinyin romanization, Nanjing's city name was spelled as Nanking or Nankin. Nanjing has a number of other names, and some historical names are now used as names of districts of the city, and among them there is the name Jiangning (江寧), whose former character Jiang (江, River) is the former part of the name Jiangsu and latter character Ning (寧, simplified form 宁, Peace) is the short name of Nanjing. When being the capital of a state, for instance, ROC, Jing (京) is adopted as the abbreviation of Nanjing. Although as a city located in southern part of China becoming Chinese national capital as early as in Jin dynasty, the name Nanjing was designated to the city in Ming dynasty, about a thousand years later. Nanjing is particularly known as Jinling (金陵, literally meaning Gold Mountain) and the old name has been used since the Warring States Period in Zhou Dynasty.
text_ai_base: Nanjing (listen; Chinese: 南京, meaning "Southern Capital") is a city located in the heartland of the lower Yangtze River region in China. It has long been a significant hub for culture, education, research, politics, economy, transportation, and tourism. As the capital city of Jiangsu province in the People's Republic of China, it is the second largest city in East China, with a population of 8,216,100. Historically, it was the legal capital of the Republic of China, which lost control of the mainland during the civil war. The name "Southern Capital" underscores Nanjing's rich historical and cultural significance, having served as the capital for various Chinese dynasties, kingdoms, and republican governments from the 3rd century AD until 1949. Before the introduction of pinyin romanization, Nanjing was spelled as Nanking or Nankin. The city also has other historical names, some of which are now used as district names, including Jiangning (江寧). Its character 'Jiang' (江, River) is part of the name Jiangsu, while 'Ning' (寧, Peace) is an abbreviated form of Nanjing. When serving as the capital city, such as for the ROC, Nanjing is abbreviated as Jing (京). Although the city became China's national capital as early as the Jin dynasty, the name Nanjing was officially given during the Ming dynasty, roughly a thousand years later. Nanjing is also famously known by its ancient name Jinling (金陵, meaning Gold Mountain), which dates back to the Warring States Period in the Zhou Dynasty.

text_human: In the United States, macabre-rock pioneer Alice Cooper achieved mainstream success with the top ten album School's Out (1972). In the following year blues rockers ZZ Top released their classic album Tres Hombres and Aerosmith produced their eponymous début, as did Southern rockers Lynyrd Skynyrd and proto-punk outfit New York Dolls, demonstrating the diverse directions being pursued in the genre. Montrose, including the instrumental talent of Ronnie Montrose and vocals of Sammy Hagar and arguably the first all American hard rock band to challenge the British dominance of the genre, released their first album in 1973. Kiss built on the theatrics of Alice Cooper and the look of the New York Dolls to produce a unique band persona, achieving their commercial breakthrough with the double live album Alive! in 1975 and helping to take hard rock into the stadium rock era. In the mid-1970s Aerosmith achieved their commercial and artistic breakthrough with Toys in the Attic (1975), which reached number 11 in the American album chart, and Rocks (1976), which peaked at number three. Blue Öyster Cult, formed in the late 60s, picked up on some of the elements introduced by Black Sabbath with their breakthrough live gold album On Your Feet or on Your Knees (1975), followed by their first platinum album, Agents of Fortune (1976), containing the hit single "(Don't Fear) The Reaper", which reached number 12 on the Billboard charts. Journey released their eponymous debut in 1975 and the next year Boston released their highly successful début album. In the same year, hard rock bands featuring women saw commercial success as Heart released Dreamboat Annie and The Runaways débuted with their self-titled album. While Heart had a more folk-oriented hard rock sound, the Runaways leaned more towards a mix of punk-influenced music and hard rock. The Amboy Dukes, having emerged from the Detroit garage rock scene and most famous for their Top 20 psychedelic hit "Journey to the Center of the Mind" (1968), were dissolved by their guitarist Ted Nugent, who embarked on a solo career that resulted in four successive multi-platinum albums between Ted Nugent (1975) and his best selling Double Live Gonzo (1978).
text_ai_base: Alice Cooper, a pioneer of macabre rock in the United States, gained mainstream popularity with his top ten album "School's Out" in 1972. The following year saw notable releases across various rock genres. Blues rockers ZZ Top unveiled their classic album "Tres Hombres," while Aerosmith, Lynyrd Skynyrd, and the New York Dolls launched their debut albums, showcasing the genre's diversity. 1973 marked the arrival of Montrose, featuring Ronnie Montrose and Sammy Hagar, as a formidable American hard rock band poised to challenge British dominance. Kiss built upon the theatrical style of Alice Cooper and the aesthetics of the New York Dolls, crafting a unique persona and achieving commercial success with their live album "Alive!" in 1975, ushering hard rock into the stadium rock era. By the mid-1970s, Aerosmith solidified their standing with "Toys in the Attic" (1975) and "Rocks" (1976), reaching notable chart positions of 11 and 3 respectively. Blue Öyster Cult, formed in the late '60s, echoed Black Sabbath's influence with their breakthrough gold album "On Your Feet or on Your Knees" (1975), followed by the platinum success of "Agents of Fortune" (1976), featuring the hit "(Don't Fear) The Reaper," which climbed to number 12 on the Billboard charts. Journey's debut in 1975 set the stage for Boston's successful first album the next year. That same year, hard rock bands with female members gained traction as Heart released "Dreamboat Annie" while The Runaways debuted their self-titled album. While Heart leaned towards a folk-inflected hard rock sound, The Runaways blended punk influences with hard rock. Ted Nugent dissolved The Amboy Dukes, known for their psychedelic hit "Journey to the Center of the Mind" (1968), to pursue a solo career resulting in four consecutive multi-platinum albums from "Ted Nugent" (1975) to "Double Live Gonzo" (1978).

text_human: It was the pub that first introduced the concept of the bar counter being used to serve the beer. Until that time beer establishments used to bring the beer out to the table or benches, as remains the practice in (for example) beer gardens and other drinking establishments in Germany. A bar might be provided for the manager to do paperwork while keeping an eye on his or her customers, but the casks of ale were kept in a separate taproom. When the first pubs were built, the main room was the public room with a large serving bar copied from the gin houses, the idea being to serve the maximum number of people in the shortest possible time. It became known as the public bar[citation needed]. The other, more private, rooms had no serving bar—they had the beer brought to them from the public bar. There are a number of pubs in the Midlands or the North which still retain this set up but these days the beer is fetched by the customer from the taproom or public bar. One of these is The Vine, known locally as The Bull and Bladder, in Brierley Hill near Birmingham, another the Cock at Broom, Bedfordshire a series of small rooms served drinks and food by waiting staff. In the Manchester district the public bar was known as the "vault", other rooms being the lounge and snug as usual elsewhere. By the early 1970s there was a tendency to change to one large drinking room and breweries were eager to invest in interior design and theming.
text_ai_base: The concept of using a bar counter to serve beer was first popularized by pubs. Before this innovation, beer was typically delivered to tables or benches, a practice still seen in beer gardens and other drinking spots in Germany. Bars existed primarily for managers to do paperwork while overseeing customers, with the ale casks stored in a separate taproom. Early pubs featured a main space known as the public room, which had a large serving bar inspired by gin houses to serve many customers quickly. This area came to be called the public bar[citation needed]. More private rooms lacked serving bars, with beer being brought in from the public bar instead. Some pubs in the Midlands or North, such as The Vine—known locally as The Bull and Bladder—in Brierley Hill near Birmingham, and The Cock at Broom, Bedfordshire, still retain this setup, though now customers fetch beer themselves from the taproom or public bar. In Manchester, the public bar was referred to as the "vault," while other areas were called the lounge and snug, as was common elsewhere. By the early 1970s, a shift toward larger, single drinking rooms began, with breweries keen to invest in interior design and themed environments.

text_human: Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment, it is not the case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic and comprise distinct phases covering a time window from seconds to even a lifetime. In fact, research has revealed that our memories are constructed. People can construct their memories when they encode them and/or when they recall them. To illustrate, consider a classic study conducted by Elizabeth Loftus and John Palmer (1974) in which people were instructed to watch a film of a traffic accident and then asked about what they saw. The researchers found that the people who were asked, "How fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other?" gave higher estimates than those who were asked, "How fast were the cars going when they hit each other?" Furthermore, when asked a week later whether they have seen broken glass in the film, those who had been asked the question with smashed were twice more likely to report that they have seen broken glass than those who had been asked the question with hit. There was no broken glass depicted in the film. Thus, the wording of the questions distorted viewers’ memories of the event. Importantly, the wording of the question led people to construct different memories of the event – those who were asked the question with smashed recalled a more serious car accident than they had actually seen. The findings of this experiment were replicated around the world, and researchers consistently demonstrated that when people were provided with misleading information they tended to misremember, a phenomenon known as the misinformation effect.
text_ai_base: Many people believe that memory works like recording equipment, but this is not accurate. The molecular processes involved in forming and maintaining memories are highly dynamic, comprising distinct phases that can last from seconds to a lifetime. Research shows that our memories are constructed, both during encoding and recall. A classic study by Elizabeth Loftus and John Palmer (1974) serves as an example. Participants watched a film of a traffic accident and were later questioned about what they saw. Those asked, "How fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other?" provided higher speed estimates than those asked, "How fast were the cars going when they hit each other?" Additionally, a week later, those questioned with "smashed" were twice as likely to report seeing broken glass compared to those asked with "hit." There was actually no broken glass in the film. Thus, the wording of the questions altered their memory of the event, leading to the construction of different memories—those questioned with "smashed" recalled a more serious accident. This effect has been replicated globally, and studies consistently show that misleading information can lead to misremembering, a phenomenon known as the misinformation effect.

text_human: On 23 April 2014, the U.S. Federal Communications Commission (FCC) was reported to be considering a new rule that will permit ISPs to offer content providers a faster track to send content, thus reversing their earlier net neutrality position. A possible solution to net neutrality concerns may be municipal broadband, according to Professor Susan Crawford, a legal and technology expert at Harvard Law School. On 15 May 2014, the FCC decided to consider two options regarding Internet services: first, permit fast and slow broadband lanes, thereby compromising net neutrality; and second, reclassify broadband as a telecommunication service, thereby preserving net neutrality. On 10 November 2014, President Barack Obama recommended that the FCC reclassify broadband Internet service as a telecommunications service in order to preserve net neutrality. On 16 January 2015, Republicans presented legislation, in the form of a U.S. Congress H.R. discussion draft bill, that makes concessions to net neutrality but prohibits the FCC from accomplishing the goal or enacting any further regulation affecting Internet service providers. On 31 January 2015, AP News reported that the FCC will present the notion of applying ("with some caveats") Title II (common carrier) of the Communications Act of 1934 to the internet in a vote expected on 26 February 2015. Adoption of this notion would reclassify internet service from one of information to one of the telecommunications and, according to Tom Wheeler, chairman of the FCC, ensure net neutrality. The FCC is expected to enforce net neutrality in its vote, according to the New York Times.
text_ai_base: On April 23, 2014, the U.S. Federal Communications Commission (FCC) was considering a new rule that would allow Internet service providers (ISPs) to offer content providers a faster pathway for content delivery, reversing its earlier stance on net neutrality. Municipal broadband may address net neutrality issues, suggested Harvard Law School’s Professor Susan Crawford, an expert in law and technology. On May 15, 2014, the FCC decided to explore two options for Internet services: firstly, allowing fast and slow broadband lanes, which would compromise net neutrality; and secondly, reclassifying broadband as a telecommunication service, which would uphold net neutrality. On November 10, 2014, President Barack Obama urged the FCC to reclassify broadband Internet as a telecommunications service to safeguard net neutrality. On January 16, 2015, Republicans proposed legislation in a U.S. Congress H.R. discussion draft bill that acknowledges net neutrality but blocks the FCC from achieving its aims or enacting further regulations impacting ISPs. On January 31, 2015, AP News reported that the FCC plans to propose applying Title II (common carrier) of the Communications Act of 1934 to the Internet—subject to certain caveats—in a vote expected on February 26, 2015. Adopting this proposal would shift the classification of internet service from information to telecommunications, ensuring net neutrality according to FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler. The FCC is expected to enforce net neutrality with its vote, as noted by the New York Times.

text_human: Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle. For most, the search for identity begins in the adolescent years. During these years, adolescents are more open to 'trying on' different behaviours and appearances to discover who they are. In other words, in an attempt to find their identity and discover who they are adolescents are liking to cycle through a number of identities to find one that suits them best. But, developing and maintaining identity (in adolescent years) is a difficult task due to multiple factors such as family life, environment, and social status. Empirical studies suggest that this process might be more accurately described as identity development, rather than formation, but confirms a normative process of change in both content and structure of one's thoughts about the self. The two main aspects of identity development are self-clarity and self-esteem. Since choices made during adolescent years can influence later life, high levels of self-awareness and self-control during mid-adolescence will lead to better decisions during the transition to adulthood.[citation needed] Researchers have used three general approaches to understanding identity development: self-concept, sense of identity, and self-esteem. The years of adolescence create a more conscientious group of young adults. Adolescents pay close attention and give more time and effort to their appearance as their body goes through changes. Unlike children, teens put forth an effort to look presentable (1991). The environment in which an adolescent grows up also plays an important role in their identity development. Studies done by the American Psychological Association have shown that adolescents with a less privileged upbringing have a more difficult time developing their identity.
text_ai_base: Identity development is a crucial stage in the adolescent life cycle, typically initiated during adolescence. At this time, adolescents explore different behaviors and appearances to understand themselves better. They often experiment with multiple identities to determine which fits them best. However, forming and maintaining identity during these years is challenging due to factors such as family dynamics, environment, and social status. Empirical studies suggest that this phase is better described as identity development rather than formation, highlighting a normative change in thoughts about the self's content and structure. Key aspects of identity development include self-clarity and self-esteem. Decisions made during adolescence can significantly impact later life, and high levels of self-awareness and self-control during these years are linked to more positive choices during the transition to adulthood.[citation needed] Researchers typically explore identity development through self-concept, sense of identity, and self-esteem. Adolescents invest considerable attention, time, and effort into their appearance as their bodies change, showing more conscientiousness compared to children (1991). The environment in which an adolescent grows significantly influences their identity development. Studies by the American Psychological Association demonstrate that those with less privileged backgrounds face greater challenges in developing their identity.

text_human: South Korea: The event was held in Seoul, which hosted the 1988 Summer Olympics, on April 27. Intended torchbearers Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun boycotted the event to protest against the Chinese government's crackdown in Tibet. More than 8,000 riot police were deployed to guard the 24-kilometre route, which began at Olympic Park, which was built when Seoul hosted the 1988 Summer Games. On the day of the torch relay in Seoul, Chinese students clashed with protesters, throwing rocks, bottles, and punches. A North Korean defector whose brother defected to China but was captured and executed by the DPRK, attempted to set himself on fire in protest of China's treatment of North Korean refugees. He poured gasoline on himself but police quickly surrounded him and carried him away. Two other demonstrators tried to storm the torch but failed. Fighting broke out near the beginning of the relay between a group of 500 Chinese supporters and approximately 50 protesters who carried a banner that read: "Free North Korean refugees in China." The students threw stones and water bottles as approximately 2,500 police tried to keep the groups separated. Police said they arrested five people, including a Chinese student who was arrested for allegedly throwing rocks. Thousands of Chinese followed the torch on its 4.5 hour journey, some chanting, "Go China, go Olympics!" By the end of the relay, Chinese students became violent, and it was reported in Korean media that they were "lynching" everyone who was disagreeing with them. One police man was also rushed to hospital after being attacked by Chinese students. On Apr 29, the Secretary of Justice, Kim Kyung Han, told the prime minister that he will find "every single Chinese who was involved and bring them to justice." Later in the day, South Korea's Prosecutor's Office, National Police Agency, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and National Intelligence Service made a joint statement saying that they will be deporting every Chinese student that was involved in the incident. China defended the conduct of the students.
text_ai_base: The event in Seoul, South Korea, took place on April 27, in the city that hosted the 1988 Summer Olympics. Designed torchbearers, Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun, boycotted the occasion to protest the Chinese government's actions in Tibet. Over 8,000 riot police were deployed to secure the 24-kilometer route starting at Olympic Park, the venue built for the 1988 Games. On the torch relay day, clashes erupted between Chinese students and protesters, with participants hurling rocks, bottles, and fists. A North Korean defector, whose brother defected to China but was caught and executed by the DPRK, attempted self-immolation to protest China's treatment of North Korean refugees. Doused in gasoline, he was quickly subdued and removed by police. Two other protesters attempted to disrupt the relay without success. Near the start, a skirmish broke out between 500 Chinese supporters and about 50 protesters waving a banner that read: "Free North Korean refugees in China." Approximately 2,500 police officers intervened as students threw stones and bottles. Five arrests were made, including a Chinese student accused of rock-throwing. Thousands of Chinese followed the torch's 4.5-hour journey, chanting, "Go China, go Olympics!" By the relay's end, Chinese students turned violent, reportedly "lynching" dissenters, as described by Korean media. A police officer was hospitalized after an attack by Chinese students. On April 29, Justice Secretary Kim Kyung Han assured the prime minister that all involved Chinese would be brought to justice. Later, South Korea's Prosecutor's Office, National Police Agency, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and National Intelligence Service jointly announced they would deport all participating Chinese students. China defended the students' actions.

text_human: Democratic Party candidates were consistently elected to local office, increasing the city's ties to the South and its dominant party. In 1861, Mayor Fernando Wood called on the aldermen to declare independence from Albany and the United States after the South seceded, but his proposal was not acted on. Anger at new military conscription laws during the American Civil War (1861–1865), which spared wealthier men who could afford to pay a $300 (equivalent to $5,766 in 2016) commutation fee to hire a substitute, led to the Draft Riots of 1863, whose most visible participants were ethnic Irish working class. The situation deteriorated into attacks on New York's elite, followed by attacks on black New Yorkers and their property after fierce competition for a decade between Irish immigrants and blacks for work. Rioters burned the Colored Orphan Asylum to the ground, but more than 200 children escaped harm due to efforts of the New York City Police Department, which was mainly made up of Irish immigrants. According to historian James M. McPherson (2001), at least 120 people were killed. In all, eleven black men were lynched over five days, and the riots forced hundreds of blacks to flee the city for Williamsburg, Brooklyn, as well as New Jersey; the black population in Manhattan fell below 10,000 by 1865, which it had last been in 1820. The white working class had established dominance. Violence by longshoremen against black men was especially fierce in the docks area. It was one of the worst incidents of civil unrest in American history.
text_ai_base: Democratic Party candidates consistently secured local office positions, strengthening the city's connection to the South and its leading political party. In 1861, Mayor Fernando Wood urged the aldermen to declare independence from Albany and the United States after the South seceded, but his idea was not pursued. New military conscription laws during the American Civil War (1861–1865) incited anger, as these laws exempted wealthier men who could pay a $300 fee (equivalent to $5,766 in 2016) to hire substitutes. This resentment led to the 1863 Draft Riots, predominantly involving ethnic Irish working class men. The violence escalated to assaults on New York's elite, and later targeted black New Yorkers and their property due to intense competition for jobs over the previous decade between Irish immigrants and blacks. Rioters torched the Colored Orphan Asylum, but more than 200 children escaped unharmed thanks to efforts by the New York City Police Department, primarily composed of Irish immigrants. Historian James M. McPherson (2001) estimated that at least 120 people were killed. In total, eleven black men were lynched over five days, prompting hundreds of blacks to flee to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and New Jersey; by 1865, Manhattan’s black population had fallen below 10,000, a level unseen since 1820, marking the rise of white working class dominance. Longshoremen's violence against black men was particularly brutal in the docks area, marking one of the most severe incidents of civil unrest in American history.

text_human: France: The torch relay leg in Paris, held on April 7, began on the first level of the Eiffel Tower and finished at the Stade Charléty. The relay was initially supposed to cover 28 km, but it was shortened at the demand of Chinese officials following widespread protests by pro-Tibet and human rights activists, who repeatedly attempted to disrupt, hinder or halt the procession. A scheduled ceremony at the town hall was cancelled at the request of the Chinese authorities, and, also at the request of Chinese authorities, the torch finished the relay by bus instead of being carried by athletes. Paris City officials had announced plans to greet the Olympic flame with peaceful protest when the torch was to reach the French capital. The city government attached a banner reading "Paris defends human rights throughout the world" to the City Hall, in an attempt to promote values "of all humanity and of human rights." Members from Reporters Without Borders turned out in large numbers to protest. An estimated 3,000 French police protected the Olympic torch relay as it departed from the Eiffel Tower and criss-crossed Paris amid threat of protests. Widespread pro-Tibet protests, including an attempt by more than one demonstrator to extinguish the flame with water or fire extinguishers, prompted relay authorities to put out the flame five times (according to the police authorities in Paris) and load the torch onto a bus, at the demand of Chinese officials. This was later denied by the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, despite video footage broadcast by French television network France 2 which showed Chinese flame attendants extinguishing the torch. Backup flames are with the relay at all times to relight the torch. French judoka and torchbearer David Douillet expressed his annoyance at the Chinese flame attendants who extinguished the torch which he was about to hand over to Teddy Riner: "I understand they're afraid of everything, but this is just annoying. They extinguished the flame despite the fact that there was no risk, and they could see it and they knew it. I don't know why they did it."
text_ai_base: On April 7, Paris hosted a leg of the torch relay, beginning on the first level of the Eiffel Tower and concluding at Stade Charléty. Initially planned to cover 28 km, the route was shortened at the insistence of Chinese officials due to widespread protests by pro-Tibet and human rights activists aiming to disrupt the event. A ceremony at the town hall was canceled at the Chinese authorities' request, and the torch concluded its journey by bus rather than with athletes running. Paris city officials had planned peaceful protests upon the torch's arrival, displaying a banner at City Hall declaring, "Paris defends human rights throughout the world," to advocate for global human rights values. Members of Reporters Without Borders joined the large protest turnout. Approximately 3,000 French police officers guarded the torch as it traversed Paris amidst protest threats. Significant pro-Tibet demonstrations, including attempts to douse the flame with water or extinguishers, led the relay authorities to extinguish the torch five times (according to Paris police) and place it on a bus, following demands from Chinese officials. This action was denied by the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, despite France 2 broadcasting footage of Chinese attendants extinguishing the flame. Backup flames are always available to relight the torch. French judoka and torchbearer David Douillet voiced his frustration when Chinese attendants extinguished the torch as he was about to pass it to Teddy Riner: "I understand they're afraid of everything, but this is just annoying. They extinguished the flame, although there was no risk, and they were aware of it. I don't know why they did it."

text_human: Israel's Supreme Court is at the head of the court system in the State of Israel. It is the highest judicial instance. The Supreme Court sits in Jerusalem. The area of its jurisdiction is the entire State. A ruling of the Supreme Court is binding upon every court, other than the Supreme Court itself. The Israeli supreme court is both an appellate court and the high court of justice. As an appellate court, the Supreme Court considers cases on appeal (both criminal and civil) on judgments and other decisions of the District Courts. It also considers appeals on judicial and quasi-judicial decisions of various kinds, such as matters relating to the legality of Knesset elections and disciplinary rulings of the Bar Association. As the High Court of Justice (Hebrew: Beit Mishpat Gavoha Le'Zedek בית משפט גבוה לצדק; also known by its initials as Bagatz בג"ץ), the Supreme Court rules as a court of first instance, primarily in matters regarding the legality of decisions of State authorities: Government decisions, those of local authorities and other bodies and persons performing public functions under the law, and direct challenges to the constitutionality of laws enacted by the Knesset. The court has broad discretionary authority to rule on matters in which it considers it necessary to grant relief in the interests of justice, and which are not within the jurisdiction of another court or tribunal. The High Court of Justice grants relief through orders such as injunction, mandamus and Habeas Corpus, as well as through declaratory judgments. The Supreme Court can also sit at a further hearing on its own judgment. In a matter on which the Supreme Court has ruled - whether as a court of appeals or as the High Court of Justice - with a panel of three or more justices, it may rule at a further hearing with a panel of a larger number of justices. A further hearing may be held if the Supreme Court makes a ruling inconsistent with a previous ruling or if the Court deems that the importance, difficulty or novelty of a ruling of the Court justifies such hearing. The Supreme Court also holds the unique power of being able to order "trial de novo" (a retrial).
text_ai_base: Israel's Supreme Court stands at the apex of the country's judicial system, serving as the highest court in the nation. Located in Jerusalem, its jurisdiction encompasses the entire State of Israel. Its rulings are binding on all other courts, except itself. The Supreme Court functions as both an appellate court and the High Court of Justice. As an appellate court, it handles appeals concerning decisions from District Courts in both criminal and civil cases, and reviews various legal and quasi-legal decisions, including those related to Knesset elections and disciplinary actions by the Bar Association. As the High Court of Justice (Hebrew: Beit Mishpat Gavoha Le'Zedek בית משפט גבוה לצדק; commonly referred to by its initials, Bagatz בג"ץ), it serves as a court of first instance, addressing the legality of actions taken by state authorities, government, local authorities, and others performing public duties. It also hears direct challenges to the constitutionality of laws passed by the Knesset. The court possesses wide discretionary power to intervene in matters requiring justice when no other court or tribunal has jurisdiction. The High Court of Justice provides relief through orders like injunctions, mandamus, and Habeas Corpus, along with declaratory judgments. The Supreme Court can also conduct a further hearing on its previous rulings. If a decision, whether rendered as an appellate court or as the High Court of Justice, is made by a panel of three or more justices, a further hearing may be convened with an expanded panel. Such a hearing is warranted if the ruling conflicts with prior decisions or if its importance, complexity, or novelty demands reevaluation. Additionally, the Supreme Court has the exceptional authority to order a "trial de novo" (a retrial).

text_human: In addition to the classical restaurants, Paris has several other kinds of traditional eating places. The café arrived in Paris in the 17th century, when the beverage was first brought from Turkey, and by the 18th century Parisian cafés were centres of the city's political and cultural life. The Cafe Procope on the Left Bank dates from this period. In the 20th century, the cafés of the Left Bank, especially Café de la Rotonde and Le Dôme Café in Montparnasse and Café de Flore and Les Deux Magots on Boulevard Saint Germain, all still in business, were important meeting places for painters, writers and philosophers. A bistro is a type of eating place loosely defined as a neighbourhood restaurant with a modest decor and prices and a regular clientele and a congenial atmosphere. Its name is said to have come in 1814 from the Russian soldiers who occupied the city; "bistro" means "quickly" in Russian, and they wanted their meals served rapidly so they could get back their encampment. Real bistros are increasingly rare in Paris, due to rising costs, competition from cheaper ethnic restaurants, and different eating habits of Parisian diners. A brasserie originally was a tavern located next to a brewery, which served beer and food at any hour. Beginning with the Paris Exposition of 1867; it became a popular kind of restaurant which featured beer and other beverages served by young women in the national costume associated with the beverage, particular German costumes for beer. Now brasseries, like cafés, serve food and drinks throughout the day.
text_ai_base: Besides its classical restaurants, Paris boasts a variety of traditional dining spots. Cafés first appeared in Paris in the 17th century, following the introduction of coffee from Turkey. By the 18th century, Parisian cafés had become vital hubs for the city's political and cultural life. One notable example from this era is the Cafe Procope on the Left Bank. In the 20th century, Left Bank cafés like Café de la Rotonde, Le Dôme Café in Montparnasse, and Café de Flore and Les Deux Magots on Boulevard Saint Germain became key gathering spots for artists, writers, and philosophers, and they remain open today. A bistro is generally considered a neighborhood eatery known for its simple decor, affordable prices, loyal patrons, and friendly atmosphere. The term "bistro" is thought to have originated in 1814 with Russian soldiers occupying the city, as "bistro" means "quickly" in Russian—reflecting their desire for fast service to return to camp promptly. Authentic bistros are becoming less common in Paris due to rising costs, increased competition from more affordable ethnic restaurants, and changing dining habits among Parisians. Initially, a brasserie was a tavern adjacent to a brewery, serving beer and food at all hours. After the Paris Exposition of 1867, brasseries gained popularity as restaurants featuring beer and other drinks, typically served by women in national costumes such as German outfits for beer. Today, like cafés, brasseries offer food and drinks throughout the day.

text_human: Chapter XI deals with evidence from biogeography, starting with the observation that differences in flora and fauna from separate regions cannot be explained by environmental differences alone; South America, Africa, and Australia all have regions with similar climates at similar latitudes, but those regions have very different plants and animals. The species found in one area of a continent are more closely allied with species found in other regions of that same continent than to species found on other continents. Darwin noted that barriers to migration played an important role in the differences between the species of different regions. The coastal sea life of the Atlantic and Pacific sides of Central America had almost no species in common even though the Isthmus of Panama was only a few miles wide. His explanation was a combination of migration and descent with modification. He went on to say: "On this principle of inheritance with modification, we can understand how it is that sections of genera, whole genera, and even families are confined to the same areas, as is so commonly and notoriously the case." Darwin explained how a volcanic island formed a few hundred miles from a continent might be colonised by a few species from that continent. These species would become modified over time, but would still be related to species found on the continent, and Darwin observed that this was a common pattern.
